thread.title: BJP hopeful, Narendra Modi to campaign hard in Bihar
thread.title_full: BJP hopeful, Narendra Modi to campaign hard in Bihar - The Times of India

author: timesofindia.indiatimes.com
title: BJP hopeful, Narendra Modi to campaign hard in Bihar
text:
NEW DELHI: Prime Minister Narendra Modi has scaled up his election rallies in Bihar refuting the allegations of BJP's rivals that his visibility was being lowered in view of adverse feedback in the first two phases of polling.
Sources dismissed speculation that rescheduling of Modi's engagements indicated BJP is losing ground and said that buoyed by popular response, the Prime Minister has been persuaded to address two additional rallies.
The Prime Minister will address a total to 22 election rallies. There will be four rallies in each of the next two phases and five in the final phase, making it clear that Modi remains the NDA's poll spearhead.
BJP is confident that it could be winning 28 to 32 seats in the first phase that saw polling in 49 assembly seats and between 20-24 seats in the second phase of 32 seats. The party feels it is poised to consolidate its gains in the subsequent rounds of polling as well.
The five Modi rallies scheduled for the last phase, that includes the Seemanchal region which with a high minority population is seen as tough going for BJP, indicates the party sees polarization working for it too.
The issues of demographic changes in the Seemanchal and nearby areas have generated a lot of public resentment and this is working in favour of BJP and the party, far from seeing the area of low returns, is working to maximize its gains.
In BJP's assessment, the Dadri lynching incident is not resonating much in Bihar while the controversy over RJD chief Lalu Prasad's remarks about beef have only served to consolidate NDA's support.
BJP does not see the Haryana chief minister M L Khattar's controversial remarks on Muslims and beef becoming an issue as the leader has said that he regrets having hurt anyone's sentiments.
The long-drawn election has taxed BJP as much as the opposition alliance and party president Amit Shah, along with several senior ministers and leaders, has been camping in Bihar for more than two weeks. Shah did the same in the Maharashtra polls last year when he spent 20-odd days in the state.
The Bihar elections have acquired an even higher profile with the result seen to have a bearing on the Modi government's capacity to steer its agenda through Parliament and take on its opponents over issues such alleged rise of intolerance and attacks on minorities and cultural critics.
